body:
Does adding the apartment attribute to the test fixture work?
On Nov 25, 2015 7:16 AM, "Casper Thygesen" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I have tried the following:
> 
> and I get:
> 
> System.InvalidOperationException : The calling thread must be STA, because many UI components require this.
> at System.Windows.Input.InputManager..ctor()
> 
> I've tried to add the Apartment attribute to TestIgnore and
> NumericTextBoxTest as well. No changes.
> Using nunit3-console.exe
> 
> ```
> public class NumericTextBoxTest
> {
>     [TestFixture]
>     public class TestIgnore
>     {
>         [Apartment(ApartmentState.STA)]
>         [TestCase(0, Key.OemMinus, true, true, "5", false)] // does not allow negative value if text is not empty
>         [TestCase(0, Key.OemMinus, true, true, "", false)] //Allows minus value if enabled
>         [TestCase(0, Key.OemMinus, true, false, "", false)] //Allows minus value if decimal values not allowed
>         [TestCase(0, Key.NumPad5, true, true, "", false)] //Allows numpad 5 value
>         [TestCase(0, Key.D6, true, true, "", false)]//Allows d6 value
>         [TestCase(1, Key.OemComma, true, true, "8", false)] //Allows decimal value if enabled and if there is a valid value
>         [TestCase(1, Key.OemComma, false, true, "0", false)] //Allows decimal value if negative not allowed
>         [TestCase(4, Key.OemComma, true, true, "-555", false)] //Allows decimal value if valid negative value inserted
>         [TestCase(0, Key.Tab, true, true, "555", false)] //Allows decimal value if valid negative value inserted
>         [TestCase(0, Key.OemComma, true, true, "", true)] //Allows decimal value without zero
>         [TestCase(0, Key.OemMinus, true, true, ",5", true)] //Allows negative decimal value without zero
>         public void NumericTextBoxInputTestNotIgnored(int caretIndex, Key key, bool allowNegativeValues, bool allowDecimalValues, string text, bool allowNoZeroDecimals)
>         {
>                 var numericTextBox = new NumericTextBox { Text = text, CaretIndex = caretIndex };
> 
>                 var isIgnored = numericTextBox.Ignore(key, allowNegativeValues, allowDecimalValues, false, false, allowNoZeroDecimals);
>                 // Assert
>                 Assert.IsFalse(isIgnored);
>         }
>     }
> }
> ```
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1066.

Nope!

I have tried:

``` csharp
 [Apartment(ApartmentState.STA)]
 public class NumericTextBoxTest
    {
```

and 

``` csharp
 public class NumericTextBoxTest
    {
        [TestFixture, Apartment(ApartmentState.STA)]
        public class TestIgnore
        {
```

and 

``` csharp
 public class NumericTextBoxTest
    {
        [Apartment(ApartmentState.STA)]
        [TestFixture]
        public class TestIgnore
        {
```

I fixed the issue!

I have --Timeout=120000 as argument on my console runner.
Removing it solves the issue.

So the NumericTextBox (framework element) is not disposed before the timeout is done.
Although I wouldn't say the accompanied error make sense!

I'm glad you managed to get it working. I am going to reopen this for confirmation though. When there is a timeout, we spawn a separate thread to run tests on so that we can cancel them. I want to confirm that running tests on an STA thread works with the timeout.
@rprouse If you are checking it out, you should try it with --workers=0 as well as in normal parallel mode.

@SimonRichards This extra thread is not always created, which may be why this bug has not been discovered. When @CasperTDK removed the --timeout option from the command-line, the extra thread was no longer needed because the fixture itself was being executed on a special queue running in the STA.

You are correct that we should not be setting the apartment state to Unknown. I think we are probably using TargetApartment == ApartmentState.Unknown to indicate that we don't care about the apartment state - not a good thing to do as it now appears. Seeing that line of code confirms the issue.
Yep same thing happened here with Apartment applied to the Fixture and Timeout attribute applied to one of the tests.

The conflict between Timeout and Apartment was fixed in PR #1202. I have unit tests on a branch that show it is fixed if you use a Timeout attribute along with the Apartment attribute on a test or fixture. It also works with the `--timeout` command line option.

As @CharliePoole suspected, it is still broken with the `--workers=0` command line.

issue.title: workers=0 conflicts with Apartment attribute
issue.body:
Fixes #1066 

The original issue was nearly fixed by PR #1202, this completes the fix for Apartment on TestFixtures.
